required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Serum Antimullerian Hormone Levels Among Epileptic Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Investigation of Serum Antimullerian Hormone Levels in Adolescent Epilepsy Patients

brief_summary.textblock: The production of AMH starts in granulosa cells before birth and the levels within the serum decreases towards the menapouse. The levels of AMH do not change throughout the menstruation cycle hovewer, it can be affected in cases related to body mass index (BMI), polycyctic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). The lower levels of AMH had been documented after ovarian surgery, radiotheraphy and chemotheraphy. AMH is a member of Transforming Growth Faktor β (TGF- β ) and it has receptors in brain structures including hyppocammpus. It is highly active neurophysiologically and it has a protective effect against N-methyl-D -aspartate related neuronal injury that is demonstrated both in vivo and in vitro studies. As a result, being a neuroactive hormone; AMH may have an effect on seizures within epileptic patients or serum AMH levels may be effected in epileptic patients when compared with healthy ones.

primary_outcome.time_frame: baseline, at the time of examination
primary_outcome.description: The comparison of serum levels of anti-mullerian hormone between epileptic and healthy groups

intervention.description: serum antimullerian hormone will be analyzed for all participants

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Healthy and epileptic volunteer females
- Ages between 12-18
- After menarche
Exclusion Criteria:
- ovarian surgery,
- history of radiotherapy
- history of chemotherapy,
- before menarche

facility.name: Near East University Faculty of Medicine

patient_data.ipd_description: Serum antimullerian hormone levels will be shared for both groups
